story:
Our mother got diagnosed with a rare form of cancer called adenoid cystic  carcinoma in June 2012, which started at the base of her tongue and continued to spread throughout her body. Unfortunately, the time has come for her body to now rest in peace. We are heart broken but so grateful to have had a wonderful mother like her. She never moaned, and still always put others before herself. 

Due to Covid restrictions, we cannot have a donation box at the funeral. Therefore, we have chosen to set up this page. Macmillan cared for our mother until her very last moment, and throughout the whole time she battled this terrible illness. The care and support they gave to our mother and our family was incredible.

story:

Lockdown has meant that collections for the British Heart Foundation have dropped due to people not being able to get out and about, visit charity shops, do collections etc so let's try and make just a little change! 

The target I have set for this challenge is £300 (that's just £10 to raise a day), but I reckon we can smash that out of the water! Currently I can successfully complete probably about 10 decent burpees, so I will be posting regular videos of me giving it my best shot on Instagram and Facebook for your enjoyment! (Any tips gladly welcome...)

Let's help beat heartbreak forever!!

story:
It was with both great shock and sadness that we recently had to inform both our team at MSC and our wider membership, of the loss of their friend and colleague Gillian Addison. Within a few weeks of Gillian feeling unwell she was diagnosed with aggressive bowel cancer which had already spread. With the support of the wonderful team at Marie Curie, Gillian's family were able to look after her at home in her final days.

Popular and well known locally, through her involvement with her church, as well as being a classmate of many of the MSC members, Gillian was destined to be a part of the Moray Sports Centre family from the moment, CEO Kathryn met her and decided "I want her on my team". 

Gillian leaves a permanent legacy behind her at MSC, as every day, the team wear a uniform designed by Gillian, whose artistic flare made a work uniform, quirky, modern, and in touch with the centre's Scottish heritage with the touch of tartan. Gillian had a savvy tech brain on her too, making sense of some of the new systems in place at the centre as well as using her passion for music, to get the sound system up and running. 

The thoughts of the team here are with her family, and especially her husband Alan, with whose help, we will be choosing an appropriate memorial to install at the centre in memory of Gillian and the amazing presence she was as part of our front of house team.

To raise funds for this, we're running an event, with proceeds being split between a memorial for Gillian and a donation to Marie Curie whose nurses were such a valuable support to the family during Gillian's final days. These nurses provide not only physical support such as pain management for their patient but also emotional support to family and friends around them.

The event will take place on the 28th of November, the current guidelines around 'group activities' mean that we will have to monitor the changing guidance continually. However, we would like to offer 60 spaces for family-friendly tasters of different classes for up to 2-hours. (A preview of the schedule will follow soon).

Everyone of all ages and abilities are welcome whether you are members or non-members. Adults £8 and Children £4. Call now to book 01343 610 670. Details of the event can also be found here on Facebook.

Gillian, thank you for sorting out our tech issues, making sure there is music in our lives, for making us the most stylish sports centre team in Scotland, for being a great member of the team, and for your friendship. You're very sorely missed.

story:
Over the past year, dying has become a front-of-mind issue for us all. The pandemic and our ageing population means its never been more pressing to make sure we have the right care and support in place to be able to protect and cherish each other as we reach the final months, weeks, days and hours of our lives. I am therefore raising money for Marie Curie as they have continued to provide their amazing services during this challenging time and are supporting more people than before. 

This year has been a tough one: living alone during a pandemic (except for with a 2 year old for part of the week) has impacted my mental health but exercising, especially upping my running distance, has helped with this.  This festive season is not going to be like normal with less celebration, so is a time I need to have a focus to keep me active. 

So far the longest run I have done is 8km. I am going to be picking a different distance to do each day from 1km (likely to be with Eric helping me) to 12km in one go.  Some days I will pick the challenge to fit around my life and work (I can't imagine Eric running 12km) but other days I will pick the distance out of a stocking. There may be some walking involved but I am going to try and run as much of it as possible. 

I don't see myself as a runner and this is not a challenge I thought I would ever see myself doing but I will give it a go so any money you can spare to donate is appreciated :-)

By the end of the trek I will have walked 25 miles and climbed over 5200 feet in less than 2 days. This will be one of the hardest challenges I have ever faced but I am so excited to have the opportunity to do this and raise money for charity!

Marie Curie is a wonderful charity that helps to provide the best environment for those living with terminal illness. They help to support those living with terminal illness as well as their families, offering expert care, guidance and support from diagnosis through to bereavement. Money raised will go directly to helping nursing staff and continuing care for the 50,000+ terminally ill people that Marie Curie help every year.

Any donations you can give are greatly appreciated to help support me on this journey!

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Prior to COVID I used to give talks to camera clubs around the UK and Europe which were popular and well received. I did not ask for a fee for these talks but simply my expenses to be reimbursed. Now we are doing everything online, so I have adapted my 'live' presentations to be delivered online using services such as Zoom. So for winter 20/21 I have decided that I will ask clubs to make a donation to WaterAid if they have enjoyed my talk.
Thank you if you are making a donation.
